Legal_Issue: Whether farm losses can be deducted from employment income when farming is not the chief source of income
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Connell spent significant time on farming but earned more from his government job; farm consistently showed losses and lacked reasonable expectation of profitability
Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayer to show farming was chief source of income
Legal_Rule: Section 31(1) limits deductible farm losses to $5,000 if farming is not the taxpayer's chief source of income
Grounds_for_Claim: Differing interpretations of 'chief source of income' under the Income Tax Act
Key_Evidence_Considered: Time spent on farming, income from employment vs. farm, history of farm losses, expectation of profit
Applicant_Challenge: Challenging limitation of farm loss deductions
Legal_Rule_Source: Section 31(1) of the Income Tax Act
Defendant_Response: Minister reassessed and limited deductions based on lack of chief source of income
Evidence_Type: Financial records, time allocation, employment income data
Remedy_Requested: Full deduction of farm losses against employment income
Outcome: Farm losses limited to $5,000 for 1979 and 1980
Decision_Authority: Appellate body reviewing Tax Court decision
Remedy_Sought: Allowance of full farm loss deductions
Governing_Rule: Section 31(1) of the Income Tax Act
